Name: BitLocker
Linux: <ref name=dislocker>https://github.com/Aorimn/dislocker FUSE driver to read/write Windows BitLocker-ed volumes under Linux / Mac OSX</ref>

Name: CipherShed
FreeBSD: <ref>http://www.truecrypt.org/misc/freebsd Although CipherShed can be built under FreeBSD  it is not recommended to run it because of bugs and instabilities when CipherShed is attempted to be used</ref>
Android: <ref name="play.google.com">https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sovworks.edslite Third party app allows to open containers encryptes with AES-256  SHA-512 hash and FAT file system</ref>

Name: CrossCrypt
Windows NT: <ref>CrossCrypt - Only for the Microsoft Windows XP/2000 operating systems</ref>

Name: Cryptainer
Windows Mobile (incl.Pocket PC): <ref>http://cypherix.com/downloads.htm PocketPC freeware release- SmartPhone beta available</ref>

Name: Cryptoloop
Windows NT: <ref name="freeotfe.org">http://www.freeotfe.org/docs/Main/Linux_volumes.htm FreeOTFE supports cryptoloop  dm-crypt/cryptsetup/dmsetup  and dm-crypt/LUKS volumes</ref>

Name: FileVault 2
Linux: <ref>https://code.google.com/p/libfvde/ libfvde supports reading FileVault2 Drive Encryption (FVDE) encrypted volumes</ref>

Name: LibreCrypt
Android: <ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nemesis2.luksmanager&hl=en_GB Third party app allows a user to open LibreCrypt compatible LUKS containers</ref>

Name: TrueCrypt
FreeBSD: <ref>http://www.truecrypt.org/misc/freebsd Although TrueCrypt can be built under FreeBSD  it is not recommended to run it because of bugs and instabilities when TrueCrypt is attempted to be used</ref>

Name: VeraCrypt
Android: <ref>https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.sovworks.eds.android Third party app allows to encrypt and decrypt VeraCrypt containers (only available in the paid version)</ref>
